headline: Spelt Pizza Dough
description: Chef John's newest recipe for pizza dough calls for the "ancient grain" spelt in sprouted flour form, and makes a delightful alternative to traditional pizza dough.

video.description: See how to make a gluten-free pizza crust!
video.name: Chef John's Spelt Pizza Dough

name: Spelt Pizza Dough
recipeIngredient: 3 cups sprouted spelt flour, or as needed, divided
1 cup warm water (100 to 105 degrees F/38 to 41 degrees C)
1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for drizzling

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk 1 cup flour, water, honey, and yeast together in a bowl. Let stand until yeast softens and mixture is bubbly, about 20 minutes.

Stir remaining flour, olive oil, and salt into yeast mixture. Beat mixture in a bowl with an electric mixer fitted with a dough hook attachment, adding more flour as necessary, until a soft and tacky dough forms, 3 to 4 minutes. Place dough in mixing bowl with a little olive oil, cover bowl with a plate, and let rise until doubled in size, 90 minutes.
Punch dough down and transfer to a lightly floured work surface. Divide into 4 balls; cover each and let rest until dough rises slightly, 30 to 45 minutes. Roll into desired shapes and thickness.

review.reviewBody: Followed the recipe and cooking technique exactly, as I always do with Chef John's recipes. My wife said it was the best pizza she has had since we moved to our mountain home 10 years ago. When we finished the personal size pizza, I combined the other 3 balls of dough and made a 14" pizza with the dough rolled out to 1/8". This one I cooked on a preheated pizza stone in a 500 degree oven for 14 minutes. EVEN BETTER! We ate it all. No more Papa Johns!
Made this using a 22 or so inch cast iron skillet in my smoker. Turned out great. Just need to increase the recipe a bit.

I have been using and loving this recipe about once a week for the past year. I love it! I can roll it out fairly thin and get something light and crispy, or leave it a little thicker, and get something more traditionally pizza-doughy. It's delicious either way. My spelt flour is not sprouted -- just plain spelt flour. It usually leavens faster than the recipe predicts, which is good, because I'm usually hungry and ready to cook faster! Thanks for this great recipe!
Thank You!!! for the awesome recipe. followed the direction exactly and it turned out perfect.

I made this exactly per directions, using whole-grain spelt flour. It came out really fantastic! I am going to try to substitute whole wheat flour next time to see how it turns out. Thank you for a winning recipe!

The instructions for making the dough were perfect (following along with the video for more details helped a lot for this inexperienced dough maker). I will say, rolling the dough out to about the size of the cast iron pan is a good size, as the ones that we rolled out thinner and cooked on a cookie sheet ended up burning in a 525 degree oven on the bottom rack for 5 minutes (cooked in the bottom of the oven because I wanted a crispy bottom). I took off one star because pizza crust is my son's favorite part, and this pizza crust was inedible for him.
This is my go-to recipe for making pizza crust, dough for Stromboli, and I’ve made several loaves of bread out of this recipe. My family said that this is the best homemade bread I’ve made.

I made this crust following the directions with no altering. It was delicious! It was easy to make and the crust was nice and crisp without being hard. I cooked it following Chef John's instructions using an iron skillet and it worked perfectly. I will definitely be making this crust again.

I loved this recipe. Followed ingredients exactly but put in the bread machine. It was a little sticky so sprayed a bowl with oil and put dough in there with a little flour and lightly kneaded. Rolled out dough and put in my large cold cast iron skillet. Baked at 475F. It was crispy and delicious.

Thanks again for a fantastic recipe, Chef John! My son is obsessed with pizza and i've been buying some for him every week. My family has been playing around with spelt flour for pancakes and some bread. This is what i've been looking for. Tried it out today and it taste great! Great tip on how to make it crunchy with a cast iron pan. Threw it in the fridge after it proofed. Took it out 30 mins before using it and it worked great!
Tried this and it turned out great!

Looks great!
I would like to know- Does this dough freeze well?

I didn't have time to let the dough rise completely so halved all the steps—and my oven only goes to 225C—it was still a very tasty dough! I used wholemeal spelt, and it was good topped with pistachio pesto, red peppers and bocconcini

Wow John! Haven't tried it with spelt yet; I will. Cast iron is my favorite item to cook with. Just about everything I own is cast iron. I was doing a lot of fireplace cooking during Irma as my power was out. This would be Incredible to cook on a campfire or grill. Never thought of pizza over the fire. I am on it! The beauty of it is taking the skillet off the stovetop and popping it right into the oven!
Phenomenal. Followed directions exactly (aside from cooking first in skillet) baked for about 15 min at 475. So easy to make and a really yummy thin crust. Thank you so much for sharing this!

This dough came together easily, and baked up nicely. It has a nice flavor, crispy texture with a bit of chew. I followed the advice from the video and heated it in a cast iron pan on the stovetop before baking, and that was a mistake. The crusts burned on the bottom, and it was unnecessary anyway, since they baked plenty crispy at 475. Next time I'll try using a pizza pan and seeing if they might be a bit chewier that way.

Just as a tip make sure you are not overzealous with the amount of dough you use for an individual pizza. After the dough rises slightly its a good idea to stretch it out relatively thin so you end up with a lighter feeling pizza. It's heavy if you use regular/fast food pizza thickness. You can also make small pizza pockets or eat thirds or halves of individual pizzas.

Tasty. But you need to do your research on spelt. It is NOT gluten-free so celiacs and other gluten-related diseases may NOT use this. It is much lower in gluten than bread wheat and has more nutrients. Makes it healthier for most of us to be sure and I use it frequently in my flour blends when I want a little more rising action. The two wheats belong to the same genera but spelt is either a different species or is a subspecies. Apparently this last issue is till being debated.
Turns out amazing baked on a pizza stone at 550!! Restaurant quality amazing!!
Just perfect. My new favorite. Actually I never had a favorite spelt pizza crust till now. This one just works.
Great recipe, the crust is thin and crispy, but everything holds together. I use regular spelt flour.

I have made many spelt pizza dough recipes, getting soggy crumby bottoms that stick to the pan....This one is hands down, the BEST. I followed the recipe to a T, and got a wonderful little pizza, with a crunchy base and a soft middle. It held up well to the toppings I added--and one of the pizzas was a meatlovers, so it had a lot of toppings on it. My family avoids wheat as we do not tolerate it very well, however we digest spelt just fine. I don't think I'll find a better recipe than this one, so I think I'll stop looking! Although I am wondering if this one might lend itself to my grill....we'll see!

This was good. I've only made pizza dough from scratch twice now, and this was the 2nd time. As an experiment, I used beer (warmed to the prescribed temp) instead of water. I'll make it again and maybe try water.
Easy to make and spelt is so much better for you. This is the only pizza base we use in our house.
